title: The rise and fall of Claudio Ranieri as he guides Leicester City to the title before being sacked nine months later
text:
Sport The rise and fall of Claudio Ranieri as he guides Leicester City to the title before being sacked nine months later The Italian's career as Leicester City boss was filled with highs and lows and will certainly go down in history Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now The rise and fall of Claudio Ranieri Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Claudio Ranieri? Really? 
They were the words Tweeted by Leicester City fan Gary Lineker when the Italian was announced Foxes boss back in July 2015. 
Ranieri made him eat his words, and present BBC Match of the Day in his pants 10 months later, when he steered his side to their first Premier League title. 
On Thursday the club announced the Italian had been sacked as manager - the result of a difficult second season. Claudio Ranieri's time at Leicester City will go down in history (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
They currently sit one point and a single place above the drop zone, and look certain to be battling for their top-flight status going into the business end of the season. 
In the above video we have compiled a timeline of the Italian's career as Foxes boss, where he fought to win fans over, brought them unimaginable success, and was relieved of his duties. 
Ranieri demonstrated his passion for perfection early on in his tenure as manager of the club. Gary Lineker presents Match of the Day in his pants (Photo: BBC) 
He guided the Foxes to second in the Premier League table in September 2015, but wanted more - he wanted a first clean sheet - and bribed his players with pizza to help them achieve it. 
By the end of November his team were sitting pretty at the top of the table after a 3-0 win over Newcastle. A game later and Jamie Vardy had broken a record - scoring in 11 successive games. 
As winter arrived Ranieri was continually asked whether his side could continue their sensational form. He toyed with the idea but ensured he wasn't getting carried away. The Foxes celebrate with their Premier League trophy during the parade (Photo: Action Images via Reuters / Jason Cairnduff) 
Until April 2016 that is, when he famously announced: "We are in Champions League man, dilly-ding, dilly-dong, come on". 
A month later and Chelsea drew 2-2 with Tottenham, meaning Leicester City became champions of England - something no one could have ever predicted (apart from those who bet on it). 
But as many musicians will tell you, that second album can be a killer, and the 2016/2017 season got off to a difficult start for the Foxes. Jamie Vardy broke a record in the title-winning season (Photo: Plumb Images) 
With the Champions League taking up half their time, Ranieri's men found themselves 11th in the table by the end of September 2016 - by no means terrible, but expectations had changed for the Italian. 
Respite came in the form of the 2016 Coach of the Year Award being gifted to Ranieri in December, but results continued to dwindle in January. 
In his final press conference ahead of the Foxes' Champions league last-16 clash with Sevilla on Wednesday evening, he announced: "We have to fight with our heads held high, chests out." Ranieri poses with his Coach of the Year Award (Photo: PA Wire) 
But his rallying cry was unable to change his fate, and just days later he was sacked. 
Announcing the news on the club's website, Vice Chairman Aiyawatt Srivaddhanaprabha said: "This has been the most difficult decision we have had to make in nearly seven years since King Power took ownership of Leicester City. 
"But we are duty-bound to put the Club's long-term interests above all sense of personal sentiment, no matter how strong that might be." poll loading Were Leicester City right to sack Claudio Ranieri? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
